snippet: Julius Agricola was the first Roman commander whoplaced garrisons along the isthmus between the riversForth and Clyde; most of his forts were on the northernside of the wall built in the reign of Antoninus Pius,a.d. 138 to 160. The venerable Bede fixes the beginning ofthe wall at old Kirkpatrick, notwithstanding that it wasextended to Dunglas between the present Cockburnspath andInnerwick,* and the end to Caerridden on the Frith ofForth, near Abercorn, which in the seventh century was theseat of an English Bishop of the Picts. The length ofthe wall is 39 Roman miles and 717 paces.

Innerwick was defended by asimilar garrison; and as both refused to surrenderto Somerset, they were honoured with an assaultwith large cannon, while hagbutters were placedso as to prevent the defenders from appearing atthe windows.
